loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie D. C. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 36 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Virgie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Virgie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Virgie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Virgie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in the city of Riwind in Pakistan with her family. She is the mother of a son who is a driver. Razia is a health worker who gives training about health issues to women in rural areas. She also sells clothes in her neighborhood to earn extra income. 

This is the first time Razia has applied for a loan from Asasah. She wants the loan for her son, who will use it to repair his vehicle named “Shahzore”. Due to the poor condition of his vehicle, he cannot drive it properly. After the repairs are done, he will be able to drive it for a longer period of time and go to the outstation as well, which will increase his chances of earning more income.

loans.use: Repair a vehicle

loans.name: Lynnie

texts.en:
Lynnie C. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 45 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Lynnie owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling animal feeds and rice in the local community. Lynnie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Lynnie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lynnie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lynnie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erdenebayar

texts.en: Erdenebayar J., 31 years old, lives with his wife and two children in a house in Hovd province in western Mongolia. His two children go to kindergarten while his wife works as an accountant in their town. Erdenebayar operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He started his business in 1998. After several successful years in business, Erdenebayar was able to afford to buy a larger, more reliable automobile. He works very hard to provide for his family and to repay his bank loan. Erdenebayar is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase parts for his automobile.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Siguidiale 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Siguidialé 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, en moyenne 4 enfants et  vivant majoritairement dans des familles polygames à Koba, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont l’arachide, le petit mil, le maïs et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, DJENEBA F. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1hectare d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Siguidialé 1 group are married women with an average age of 45 and an average of four children. Mostly, they live in polygamous families in Koba, a village in the prefecture of Dioila, Koulikoro region (Mali's Second Administrative District). They work with Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their activities as the rainy season begins. They grow peanuts, millet, corn and beans. This will be their third seasonal loan. Their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, Djeneba F. will buy fertilizer and small tools and pay for hired labor to work one hectare of peanuts and beans. The harvest will be sold in the village of Nangola and the surrounding area and in the town of Dioila to both men and women. The group members hope for an average profit of CFA 45,000 at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay hired labor, buy fertilizer and small tools

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda M. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 46 years old and married with six adult children. To make a living, Minda owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products. Minda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Minda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Minda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Idersuren

texts.en: Idersuren Z. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife Olzbayar recently gave birth to twins. Idersuren began his meat trading business in 2008. He is planning on expanding his business and buying more stock in order to increase sales and his quality of life. Idersuren is requesting a 1,000,000MNT loan in order to purchase more meat wholesale for his meat trading business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira D. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 50 years old and married with six adult children. To make a living, Elvira owns a business selling home products. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elvira from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Siguidiale  2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Siguidialé 2 sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koba, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités au début de l’hivernage. Les spéculations sont l’arachide, le petit mil, le maïs, le sésame et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, DJITA M. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1 hectare d’arachide et de mil.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Siguidialé 2 are married women who average 43 years of age and four children.  They lives for the most part in polygamous families in Koba, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to organize their businesses better at the start of winter.  The crops are peanuts, pearl millet, corn, sesame, and beans.  The group members are on their third farm loan.  The past loans have been settled.  With this new loan, DJITA M. intends to buy supplies and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining one hectare of peanuts and millet.  After the harvests, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of women and men in and around the village of Nangola and in the city of Dioïla. The group members plan on making an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies and equipment and paying hired hands

loans.name: Perveen Akhter's Group

texts.en: Perveen akhter is a resident of Riawind, Pakistan. She is the mother of three sons. One of her sons sells milk and yogurt and another has a cycle repair shop. Her husband is a security guard and she helps financially by doing sewing for her neighbors. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to support her son who wants to buy milk to expand his business. This is the fourth time Perveen Akhtar will get a loan from Asasah. She is hopeful that this loan will be a helpful for her son’s business. Her credit history is very good and she is never late in making payments.

loans.use: Purchase milk for a dairy business

loans.name: Melvien

texts.en:
Melvien E. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 43 years old, single and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Melvien owns a business selling home products especially cosmetics. Melvien has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melvien joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Melvien from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Siguidiale  3 Group

texts.fr:
Siguidialé 3 est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans,  4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koba, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont l’arachide, le petit mil, le maïs et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, TENIN B. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1,7 hectares d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs venant des grandes villes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice 45 000FCFA  en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
Siguidialé 3 is a group of ten married women who, on average, are 34-years old, have four children, and live mostly in polygamous families in Koba, one of the villages of the Dioïla prefecture in the Koulikoro area, Mali's second administrative region. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to carry out their winter activities.The crops they speculate are peanut, millet, corn and beans. This is their third campaign loan, and past loans have been repaid without incident. With this new loan, TENIN B. plans to buy seedlings and small farming equipment, and pay for labor costs necessary to maintain 1.7 hectares of peanuts. After the harvest, produce is sold in the village of Nangola and surrounding neighborhoods of the city of Dioïla to a clientele consisting primarily of retailers from the big cities. Tenin expects to end the season with a profit of 45,000F CFA.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seedlings and small farming equipment, and pay for labor

loans.name: Margaret Alila

texts.en:
Margaret Alila A., 60 years old, is a widow with 7 children. The family lives in Oruba estate in Migori town. Some of Margaret's children are married and only one is still in school.

Margaret sells cereals at Onyinjo market. She has been in this business for the past 30 years. Her clients consist mainly of people who come to the market to shop. Margaret was introduced to Kadet Ltd. by some clients after she saw how they were benefiting from the loans they were receiving. This is Margaret's second loan, having completing the first one without problem. Her main hope and dream is to expand her business and her capital base.

loans.use: to buy more cereals to add to her stock

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora N., 62 years old, is a widow, her husband having passed away some years ago. She has 9 children; some are married and some are in college. They live in the Nyamome area in Migori.

Flora has been selling maize for the last nine years. She does her business at Muhuru stage. Most of her clients buy the maize from her and take it to a maize grinding machine to be turned into flour. Flora's business has enabled her to support her family well and to cater for her children who are in college. She is applying for KES 20,000 as her fourth loan. She has a good credit history with Kadet since she has never defaulted on her loans. Flora expects to open up a bigger store where she will carry a larger stock of cereals. She also expects a big improvement to her business by using the loans from Kadet / Kiva to buy a grinding machine (posho mill) and improve her family's welfare.

loans.use: to buy maize to add to her stock

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en: Lhagvasuren B., 38 years old, lives with his wife and two daughters in Uvurhangai province, central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Lhagvasuren’s wife is a student at the Medical college in Darhan city and his daughters attend a local middle school. Lhagvasuren operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He also runs a drinking water distribution service into his own fence where the family lives. He says, "I am trying my best to afford my wife's tuition fees and have started saving money for my elder daughter who is going to be a student soon." Since he began the business, he has gained a lot of experience and is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wool at a wholesale price in order to increase his earnings.

loans.use: To purchase wool to sell

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en: Novelyn C. is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 44 years old. Novelyn is widowed and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Novelyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products, especially soft drinks, in the local community. Novelyn has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 5,600 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Novelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Novelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Novelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: madame T. ama est mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de Attiégou qui est un quartier périphériques de la ville de lomé. en 2000 elle a débuté le commerce de chaussures, elle a associé plus tard à ce commerce la vente de sacs de sortie pour dame ce qui lui a permis d'accroître ses revenus. elle sollicite chez WAGES son premier prêt pour s'approvisionner avec une vingtaine de chaussures et une quinzaine de sacs pour dame.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. Ama is married and a mother of 3. She lives in Attiégou, a neigbourhood just outside of Lomé. She started a shoe business in 2000. She later started selling handbags, which has allowed her to increase her revenue. She is requesting her first WAGES loan to stock up on 20 pairs of shoes and 15 handbags.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes and handbags

loans.name: Siguidiale 4 Group

texts.fr:
Siguidialé 4 est un groupe constitué de 10 femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 23 ans, 2 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à Koba, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont l’arachide, le petit mil, le maïs, le sésame et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, BAMA K. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1hectare d’arachide et de mil.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
Siguidialé 4 is a group of ten married women with an average age of 23 and an average of two children. They live in polygamous families in Koba, a village in the prefecture of Dioila, Koulikoro region (Mali's Second Administrative District). They work with Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their rainy-season activities. They grow peanuts, millet, corn, sesame and beans. This will be their third seasonal loan. Their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, Bama K. will buy fertilizer and small tools and pay for hired labor to work about one hectare of peanuts and millet. The harvest will be sold in the village of Nangola and the surrounding area, and in the town of Dioila. The customers are both men and women. The group members hope for an average profit of CFA 45,000 at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and small tools and pay for hired labor

loans.name: Godfrey Wasonga

texts.en:
Godfrey Wasonga O. was born in 1984 and is 26 years old. He is married to Lillian Owingu and they don't have any children. They live in the Mapera area in the outskirts of Migori town. 

Godfrey has been running his shop for the past three years and has seen his business grow through the years. He was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a friend. He wants to borrow 80,000 Kenyan shillings to enable him to buy some sugar, flour, soft drinks and other foodstuffs to add to his shop. His shop is in Mapera market, approximately 7km from Migori town. The market serves as a meeting point of three small towns that neighbor it, which makes him have a big clientele.

He hopes in the next few years, he will be able to open a supermarket and also employ people to enable him to run this business.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, flour and foodstuff to stock his shop

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou O. is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 31 years old. Marilou is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma G. is from the village of Poblacion, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 30 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns and operates a bakeshop, baking and selling a variety of staple products including bread in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Wilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Tiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tiessiri 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du  Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide, le maïs et le gombo. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SOKONA K. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ,4 hectares d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 65.000FCFA environs en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Tiessiri 1 are married women who average 38 years of age and four children.  They live for the most part in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their businesses at the start of winter.  The crops are peanuts, corn, and okra.  The group members are on their third farm loan, and the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, SOKONA K. intends to buy supplies (before prices rise) and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining 1.4 hectares of peanuts.  After the harvest, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of women and men in the cities of Dioïla and Fana. She plans to make a profit of about 65,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for supplies, equipment, and manual labor

loans.name: Myadagmaa

texts.en:
Myadagmaa B. is a 55 year old widow who lives with her children in Uvurhangai province in the central part of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter is a student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Myadagmaa operates a drinking water delivery service nearby the ger districts and manages a food, consumer goods and mobile phone business in her town with the help of her children.  Myadagmaa’s personal goal for the near future is to be able to pay for her daughter’s university tuition fees and keep her family comfortable and well fed.

She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of goods and clothes in Ereen, a city on the border with China, in order to expand her business line to keep growing customer base.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Fazilat

texts.en:
Fazilat has applied for a loan to financially help her son who has a business selling spare parts. 

She lives in a three-room brick house in Riwind, which is a small city near Lahore. She works part time as a seamstress and stitches clothes for her neighborhood clients.

Her husband is a wagon driver and her other two sons are also drivers. Their sons couldn’t study further after their matriculation due to financial reasons and had to work to support their family.

This is the fourth time that Fazilat has applied for a loan from Asasah. She has maintained good credit behavior with Asasah and didn't delay with repayments. Earlier she received a loan for starting of her son’s business and now she wants to help him expand his business.

She is fifty-four years of age and a housewife and at this older age she wants to see her son married in her lifetime. She will save money for her son from the profit.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for reselling

loans.name: Akuavi Massan

texts.fr: A. est une femme très dynamique, depuis 3 ans déjà elle s'est lancée dans le commerce de tissus pour la confection de chemises, pantalons et autres vêtements. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes mais elle réalise de plus grandes recettes en vendant à des personnes âgées qui manifestent régulièrement le besoin. vu la demande élevée de sa clientèle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de Tissus. elle est mariée et réside dans le quartier de adidomé à lomé.
texts.en:
Ms. A. is a very energetic woman. Three years ago, she got started in the commerce of cloth for making shirts, pants, and other clothing. Her customer base includes anyone, but she makes the most from selling to older people, who demonstrate a regular need. Given the high demand from her customers, Ms. A. is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying cloth. She is married and resides in the Adidomé district in Lomé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Tiessiri 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Tiessiri 2 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont ’arachide,   le petit mil, le maïs et le gombo. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, MARIA D. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production  est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 35.000FCFA environ en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Tiessiri 2 are married women who average 38 years of age and five children.  They live for the most part in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of organizing their businesses better at the start of winter.  The crops are peanuts, pearl millet, corn, and okra.  The group members are on their third farm loan, and the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, MARIA D. intends to buy supplies (before prices rise) and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining one hectare of peanuts.  After the harvest, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of women and men in the cities of Dioïla and Fana. The group members plan on making an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA, approximately, at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for supplies, equipment, and manual labor

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en: Myagmarsuren S. is 20 years old and lives with his parents in a house in Arhangai province in the central part of Mongolia. He began his food selling business in 2008 with the help of his parents and with working capital of 2,500,000 MNT. Since then, he has been earning enough money to greatly improve their quality of life. Now his working capital exceeds 4,000,000 MNT. With the business earnings, he is able to afford his university tuition fees. Myagmarsuren is a modest man who is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to help him purchase a large amount of a variety of food.

loans.use: To  purchase inventory

loans.name: Tiessiri 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tiessiri 3 sont  des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et ont en moyenne    4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide,   le petit mil, le maïs et le gombo. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont  été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt,  SALI T. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 65.000FCFA environs en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group Tiessiri 3 are married women who average 34 years of age and four children.  They live for the most part in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their businesses at the start of winter.  The crops are peanuts, pearl millet, corn, and okra.  The group members are on their third farm loan, and the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, SALI T. intends to buy supplies (before prices rise) and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining one hectare of peanuts.  After the harvest, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of retailers in the city of Dioïla. She plans on making a profit of about 65,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for supplies, equipment, and manual labor

loans.name: Naidanjav

texts.en:
Naidanjav C. is 57 years old and lives with her husband and a daughter in their own house in Arhangai province, central Mongolia. Her husband is retired and her daughter is a student. Naidanjav manages a business selling satellite antennas in her town.

Naidanjav began a clothes selling business in 2000 with working capital of 700,000 MNT and gained much experience. Based on her many years in business, she made a contract with a local company in order to supply satellite antennas which she imports from Ereen, a border city inf China. Now her working capital has reached 3,800,000 MNT. Naidanjav is a modest, energetic and optimistic person. She says, “I wish I could afford my daughter's tuition fees and create new success for my family." Naidanjav is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of satellite antennas for her business.

loans.use: To purchase satellite antennas to sell

loans.name: Tiessiri  4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tiessiri  4 est constitué de 10 femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide,  le petit mil, le maïs et le gombo. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, MAMOU B. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,3  hectare de maïs  et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25.000FCFA environs en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The Tiessiri 4 group is made up of ten married women with an average age of 47 and an average of four children. They mostly live in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in the prefecture of Dioila, Koulikoro region (Mali's Second Administrative District). They work with Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their activity as the rainy season begins. They grow peanuts, millet, corn and okra. This will be their third seasonal loan. Their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, Mamou B. will buy fertilizer before its price goes up. She will also buy small tools and will pay for hired labor to work about 1.3 hectares of corn and peanuts. The harvest will be sold in Dioila and Fana to both men and women. The group members hope for an average profit of CFA 25,000 at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hire labor and buy fertilizer and small tools

loans.name: Tiessiri 5 Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Tiessiri 5 sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide,   le petit mil, le maïs, le niébé et le gombo. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SITAN C., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,2 hectare d’arachide et de niébé.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 45.000FCFA environs en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the group Tiessiri 5 are married women who average 37 years of age and three children.  They live for the most part in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their businesses at the start of winter.  The crops include peanuts, corn, black-eyed peas, and okra.  The group members are on their third farm loan, and the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, Ms. SITAN COUMAR, the president of the group, intends to buy supplies (before prices rise) and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining 1.2 hectares of peanuts and black-eyed peas.  After the harvest, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of women and men in the cities of Dioïla and Fana.    She plans to make a profit of about 45,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for supplies, equipment, and manual labor

loans.name: Surenhuu

texts.en:
Surenhuu D. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and seven children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house. Her husband works as a driver for a local private company. 

Surenhuu operates a flour retailing business in her town. She started her business in 1998 and over the years, Surenhuu has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. Her business is very important to her and her family, because she pays for three children's tuition fees with the earnings of her business. 

Surenhuu is an open-minded, easy-going and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A. is a 77-year-old single woman. Twelve years ago, she opened herself up to taking the risk of venturing in a business through the motivation of her business partner Rita, who is now 80 years of age. The two had their own share of a small amount of capital to start a business of buying and selling salt and “muscovado” sugar. They have a small table made of bamboo in the market to sell their products to people. 

“Mucovado” is a variety of sugar which is commonly called the “red" sugar. It is processed naturally and free from any chemicals and preservatives. This is supposedly the most expensive kind of sugar, wherein customers are people from class A and B. However, in the province where the supply of this is abundant and the sellers' packaging and marketing strategies are very poor, the demand in the market is low. Middlemen buy large volume and are the ones to improve the packaging for export, selling in other cities through malls. Therefore, they’re the ones who gain bigger profit.  

Despite Victoria’s age, she still has hopes to improve the packaging of her business and to increase her sales turnover. With that, she will have more profits and her dream of helping some of her relatives would be materialized.

loans.use: To purchase larger volume of "muscovado" sugar and salt for selling

loans.name: Tiessiri 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tiessiri 6 est constitué de sept des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à Tiendo, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide,   le petit mil, le maïs et le gombo. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et les précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SITAN C. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 47.000FCFA environs en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The group Tiessiri 6 is composed of seven women who average 42 years of age and five children living in polygamous families in Tiendo, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their businesses at the start of winter.  The crops include peanuts, pearl millet, corn, and okra.  The group members are on their third farm loan, and the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, Ms. SITAN C. intends to buy supplies (before prices rise) and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining one hectare of peanuts.  After the harvest, the produce is sold to a customer base composed of retailers in the city of Fana.    She plans to make a profit of about 47,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for supplies, equipment, and manual labor

loans.name: Bukasa Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Making the best out of the incessant bad bargains that come with plying a cutthroat business is what 45-year-old Edward S. can speak authoritatively on. In his 14 year checkered history overseeing his brick-laying and sand-quarry businesses, he has been brought to terms with the requisite virtues that are needed to make successful headway in firmly establishing a business niche. 

A lot of sacrifices have to be made to get that leeway, especially when one is an upstart businessperson. An unwavering sense of purpose, hard work and determination are vital means to achieving one’s ends in any business, according to this affable and buoyant gentleman. He also points out that a belief in one’s abilities is paramount.

The vestiges of his first business experience can be traced to his erstwhile diary and still existing retail enterprise. These two businesses were both gotten off their feet with a lot of persuasion from friends. 

In Bukasa, his sand and brick products are in high demand. This he attributes to the good rapport he has created with his customers. These customers return the favor by bringing in other customers. He says it is mostly middle-class people constructing family homes who are his clients. 

The happily married father of four says he has made profitable use of his businesses. In a month, his balance sheet profits add to 400,000 shillings. He also still ekes out side profits from his retail shop. Educating all his children to higher institutions of learning is his highest priority for now and the future. With this loan, he is upbeat that he will be in a much stronger financial position to buy more firewood that he requires to bake his bricks.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for baking his bricks

loans.name: Gradi Plus Group

texts.en:
Adolphine W. is the leader of the Community Bank named “Gradi Plus” which is composed of 31 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Adolphine has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2007. She runs a general store to the Southwest of Kinshasa. She has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize her dream of one day opening a large store in her environment. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that earns her $28 per week. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. 

Adolphine has already obtained twice and correctly repaid loans from the micro-finance institution, HOPE DRC.  She will increase her stock of merchandise with her loan from Kiva by buying women’s clothes and reselling them at a profit. 42 years old, Aldophine is married and the mother of four children, whose ages vary between 7 and 16 years old.  All of them attend school.

loans.use: increasing her stock by buying women’s clothes and reselling for a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Tungalagtamir

texts.en:
Tungalagtamir L. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arhangai province, in the central part of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband works as a welder and helps her out with her business.  Her elder two daughters are students and her youngest son attends a local high school.  Tungalagtamir is happy that she is able to afford her daughters' tuition fee with her business earnings.

Tungalagtamir operates a retail business selling dairy products in her town at the local market. She started her business in 1994 with working capital of 50,000 MNT.  Her working capital now exceeds 2,000,000 MNT.  She attributes her business success to her knowledge of local market demands. She is requesting a 2,900,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy products to sell at a retail price.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Assumpta

texts.en: Assumpta will use this loan to buy dry beans for reselling. She is a 50-year-old woman. Her husband is retired and together they have two children. Assumpta also looks after four children for her sister and she lives in a family of six people. She sells fresh foods and also secondhand shoes – something she has done for 10 years. Assumpta says she started with a retail shop selling other domestic items but she is now specializing in fresh foods and vegetables and hopes to have more stock for a business that can be run with little debt attached.

loans.use: To purchase beans for reselling

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya B. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, in the western part of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. She has purchased fenced-in land where the family lives. Her two children attend a local middle school while her husband runs a raw materials trade business in their town.

Tuya makes felt products such as slippers, hats and seat cushions.  She also makes a variety of souvenirs which are sold at a souvenir stall at the town market. Tuya began her craft business in 2006 and has since expanded her product line.  Her plan is to buy a spinning machine in order to produce more items.  She also plans to participate in trade fairs which are organized in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Tuya is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to buy a spinning machine in order to keep her business growing.

loans.use: To purchase spinning machine

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr: T. akou est une femme célibataire et dynamique, elle vit dans le quuartier de Agou qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. pour se prendre en charge et satisfaire ses propres besoins, elle a  entamé le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 3 ans déjà. son stock actuel est en baisse, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 2 sacs de riz, 2 bidons d'huile, 3 cartons de tomates et 2 sacs de sucre. avec ce stock elle compte accroître ses recettes.
texts.en:
T. Akou is an energetic woman who is unmarried and living in Agou, an outlying district of the city of Lomé. To support herself, she started working in the commerce of groceries. She has been in this business for three years already. Akou's inventory is currently low. She would like to stock up again. This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying 2 sacks of rice, 2 containers of oil, 3 boxes of tomatoes, and 2 sacks of sugar. With this inventory, she expects to increase her income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is to use the loan funds to finish construction of his house and also to purchase timber for his carpentry business.

Richard is a 36-year-old man with two children aged 7 and 12 years. He lives in his own house and has a dream of educating his children and also acquiring more land.

Richard is a carpenter, a business he has done for fourteen years. He first did crafts then went into timber. At the moment, he is sharing the carpentry shop with others but he hopes to have his own soon.

loans.use: To finish construction of his house and to purchase timber for his carpentry business

loans.name: Winner Plus Group

texts.en:
“Winner Plus” is a group of 18 owners of small businesses. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.  The group is chaired by Brigitte.

Brigitte sells second-hand clothing and shoes.  She became a micro entrepreneur in 2008. Her business is located in the middle area of Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. 

She has received already one loan from the microfinance institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid it. She intends to use this loan to expand her inventory. She will buy a bundle of second-hand clothing in order to resell it and increase her working capital. Currently she earns a profit of $240 per week. Brigitte is 37 years old, married and the mother of four children aged 3 to 14. Three of them attend school. Her dream is to someday open a transportation enterprise.

loans.use: purchasing a bundle of second hand-clothing to resell in order to increase her working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.en:
Ablavi D. is 40 years old and lives and works in Lomé, Togo. She sells a traditional Togolese dish called pâte, a sort of dough that is eaten with different kinds of meat and a spicy sauce. Madame D. usually sells her pâte with chicken. She has been in this business since 2000. 

She is married to a chauffeur and they have 4 children. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES of 500,000 CFA in order to purchase more supplies for making the pâte.  She will also use the funds to purchase casserole dishes and bowls that she uses to serve her meals to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase corn, dishes and bowls

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr: K. amélé est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle habite avec sa famille dans le quartier de soviépé à lomé. pour apporter sa contribution financière aux charges du ménage, elle a entamé en 2006 le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, elle a ouvert à cet effet une boutique qu'elle a appeléé "LIHOCO Commerce  général", elle s'approvisionne à Lomé. son stock est en baisse elle voudrait s'approvisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits d'alimentation générale.
texts.en:
K. Amélé is a married woman and the mother of two children. She lives with her family in the Soviépé district in Lomé. To do her financial share for the household, she started a grocery business in 2006. To this end, she opened a store that she called "LIHOCO Commerce Général". Amélé gets her supplies in Lomé. Her stock of goods is low, so she would like to stock up again. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying various grocery items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a lady of 55 years and is a single mother with three children. She dream of constructing her own residence as she is now staying in a house owned by her brother.

Margret operates a retail shop in Hoima and has been in the business for sixteen years. Previously, she was employed as a nurse at a local health unit.

Margret says she wants to have a big wholesale shop one day. She is to purchase sugar, juice and cooking oil to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, juice and cooking oil for her shop

loans.name: Gnonoussi

texts.fr: cette femme malgré ses 50 ans est une femme très dynamique exerce toujours son métier de couture, elle a 3 personnes à sa charge et c'est cette activité qui lui permet de subvenir à leurs besoins. elle a reçu des commandes de ses clients mais ne peut les satisfaire à cause de  du manque de certains matériaux de travail, elle souhaite s'approvisionner c'est pour cette raison qu'elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour l'achat de fermetures, grippures, fils et autres.
texts.en:
Despite her age, this very dynamic 50-year old woman still carries on her dressmaking trade. She has three dependants, and this activity allows her to provide for their needs. Unable to fill the orders placed by her customers due to a shortage of supplies, she requested a loan from WAGES to purchase sewing notions including fasteners, guipure, thread and more.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabric and sewing notions

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de fruits et laitues, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2006 et s'approvisionne à Lomé, elle fait face en ce moment à une rupture de stock raison pour laquelle elle demande un prêt pour l'achat de divers fruits comme l'avocat, les mangues, les papayes, la salade, des oranges et autres pour s'approvisionner. elle est marié et mère de 4 enfants
texts.en:
This lady earns her living with her retail business of fruit and lettuce; she has been doing this business since 2006 and gets her supplies at Lome. She is currently facing a stock outage, which is why she asked for a loan in order to purchase various fruits such as avocados, mangos, papayas, lettuce, oranges and others to stock up. She is married and mother of 4 children.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fruits

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne is to use the loan funds to buy saucepans, plates and flasks for her restaurant business.

Roselyne is a 40-year-old mother of five children, all of school-going age, who is married to a businessman. Together, they live in a simple home in Hoima, Uganda. She says she wants to educate her children so that they can have a good life in the future.

Roselyne operates a restaurant, a business she has been in for the last six years, her major hardship being the lack of a reliable labor force. She started selling pancakes, then bread and textiles until she opened her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy saucepans, plates and flasks for her restaurant business

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a 34 year old woman who is a member of Faulu Kenya under Bukima Lady’s group.  She saves her money with the group on a weekly basis.  This has helped her to improve her business. She has been guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES by the group members. 

Rachael opened a salon a year ago.  Currently, she has many customers because of her good service. She hopes to expand her salon and add salon equipment in order to provide better service.  With this loan, Rachael will purchase a hairdryer, a blow-drier and other hair products.

loans.use: To purchase hair drier, hair blow drier and hair products.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mawuli

texts.fr: cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2003 déjà et s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, le stock actuel dont elle dispose ne lui permet pas de satisfaire ses clients. elle veut s'approvisionner et sollicite par conséquent de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits d'alimenation générale. elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant.
texts.en:
This lady earns her living with her retail business of grocery; she has been doing this business since 2003 and gets her supplies in the large market of Lome. Her current stock is not sufficient to satisfy her customers’ demand; she wishes to stock up and is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to purchase various grocery products. She is married and mother of one child.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing grocery products

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 51 years old, married, and the mother of three, aged 28, 26 and 10.  She sells secondhand clothes in an open air market called Toi Market.  She has been in this business for twenty years.  She also does tailoring as her part time job.  

She joined a group which consists of women entrepreneurs in Faulu Kenya with the aim of sharing business ideas, saving her money and being guaranteed her loan.  Through the group, she wants to take out her first loan of 20,000 KES.  She will use this loan to buy more clothes to sell.  She believes that with additional stock she will get more income.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Waly Dioulbe Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité WALY DIOULBE fait partie du Banc Villageois de VELINGARA FOULBE MAREWE. Il est composé de 10 femmes issues du même quartier.

Le groupe a été crée depuis le 17 juillet 2006. Les membres se sont organisés par proximité et par affinité. 

Mariama B., tout à fait à droite de la photo envoilée en blanc est responsable du Groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 51 ans. Elle est mariée et mère 12 enfants et tutrice de 02 autres qui lui sont confiés par des proches.

Elle fait de la restauration et son prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en denrée alimentaire pour mieux développer son activité. 

Son objectif est de participer au payement de la scolarité de ses enfants et de soutenir son mari dans les charges familiales
texts.en:
The solidarity group WALY DIOULBE is part of the Banc Villageois of Velingara Foulbe Marewe. It is composed of ten women from the same district and was created on July 17, 2006. The group members organized themselves by proximity and affinity. Ms. Mariama B. (at the far right in the photo and wearing a white veil) is the leader of the solidarity group. She is 51 years old, married, and the mother of 12 children. She is also the guardian of two others, who are entrusted to her by relatives. Mariama works in food catering. Her loan will enable her to stock up on foodstuffs in order to develop her business further. Her goal is to help cover schooling costs for her children and to help her husband to meet family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying provisions in order to develop her restaurant

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 43 years old and married with six children.  Four of her children are still in school.  She has been doing beauty therapy for four years.  She also sells fabric and handbags to supplement her income.  

She is a new member of Faulu Kenya, in the Bukima lady’s group, and wants to take out her first loan of 20,000 KES.  She will use this loan to purchase beauty products and salon equipment.  She wants to invest in her business so as to get enough capital for opening a cosmetic shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and salon equipment

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 50-year-old mother of three children aged 30, 27 and 24, who are in school.  She sells ladies underwear, fabric and scarves.  She has been in this business for three years. 

She joined Faulu Kenya in Bukima Lady’s group, whose members guarantee each other's loans.  Through the group, she has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add to her stock of clothes. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin is a 26-year-old married man with three children.  His wife earns a living through tailoring while he does carpentry. He belongs to the Mijingo Self Help Group whose members guarantee each other's loans.  In the group, he also saves his money on a weekly basis.  

Edwin has been operating his business for three years. Because he wants to buy more timber and hardware tools, he has requested a loan of 20,000 KES.  He hopes to own a furniture showroom in the future.

loans.use: To buy more timber and hardware tools

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr: cette dame est âgée de 31 ans, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis  plus de 3 ans déjà et elle en a une parfaite maîtrise,  sa clientèle est élevée, elle veut les satisfaire tous raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de wages un prêt pour pouvoir s'acheter  10 sacs de maïs et divers produits d'alimentation générale. elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. elle a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé.
texts.en:
This woman is 31 years old, and her business consists in selling food staples. She's been running this business for more than three years now, and already knows all the ins and outs. She has a large clientele, and want to satisfy all her customers. This is why she's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy 10 sacks of corn and other food products. She's married and the mother of two children. She already benefited from one loan from WAGES, which was repaid without problems.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 sacks of corn and other food products

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a 47-year-old single lady.  She does dressmaking and embroidery to earn a living.  As a single mother of two, she works hard to provide for her family.  

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, in Bukima Lady's group, she has managed to improve her business, using her savings with the group. Currently, she can afford to pay wages to her two employees. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to buy fabric for making clothes.  She hopes to open a textile shop and a boutique shop within five years.

loans.use: To buy fabric for making clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more millet and other ingredients to prepare more porridge to sell

loans.name: C2328 Abahujumutima Group

texts.en:
Rambert is 40 years old and is married with four children aged between 5 and 12. In this family, only Rambert works and so he has to work hard so that he provides everything necessary for his family.

Rambert is a businessman selling fruit and cakes and this business is fruitful for him, he said. Rambert is also the leader of this group which is called Abahujumutima. The group contains five women and one man; most of them are in the business of selling foodstuffs.

Rambert and his group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses. Once their businesses are expanded, they hope to satisfy their customers and earn more profits.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Nafaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité NAFAYA est créé le 17 juillet 2006 il fait partie du Banc Villageois de VELINGARA FOULBE MAREWE. Il est composé de 10 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier. 

Les membres du Groupe se sont organisés par affinité et par centre d'intérêt, c'est-à-dire développer des activités commerciales.

Madame Nafy D., à droite de la photo en grand boubou rouge bordeaux, elle la présidente du Groupe de Solidarité. Elle est âgée de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants et a la charge d'un enfant qui lui est confié par des proches. 

Elle fait la fabrique et vente de glaces et de crèmes glacées. Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter des condiments pour la production de crèmes glacées d'une part, et payer les factures d'électricité liées à la fabrique de glace d'autre part. 

Son objectif est de est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge familiale surtout pour la dépense quotidienne et la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group NAFAYA was created on July 17, 2006. It is part of the Banc Villageois of Velingara Foulbe Marewe and is composed of ten women who are all from the same district. The group members organized themselves by affinity and by interest center, that is, business development. Ms. Nafy D. (at the right in the photo and wearing a large Bordeaux red boubou) is the president of the solidarity group. She is 46 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She also has a child in her care who is entrusted to her by relative. Nafy makes ice and ice cream and sells them. Her new loan will allow her to buy condiments for making ice cream but also to cover the electricity bill associated with making ice. Her goal is to support her husband in meeting family expenses, especially day-to-day expenses and the schooling costs for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying condiments for making ice cream

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Mohamed S.. Born in a village call Malal Mara, in northern Sierra Leone, this husband and father of eight children is a businessman with a small-scale business in Makeni city. His wife is a businesswoman too and three of his children are attending either primary or secondary schools.

Mohamed has been selling shoes for twenty-two years now. His shoes business has enjoyed a massive growth, thanks to previous SMT/Kiva loans. Nevertheless, he is still not complacent; having repaid his last loan successfully, he now wants a new loan of SLL 3,000,000 in order to further improve his business.

With the help of this SLL 3,000,000 loan, Mohamed will be able to buy at least a bale of shoes to add to his stock.

loans.use: To buy at least a bale of shoes to add to his stock

loans.name: Lane Kuru - V Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Lane Kuru - V” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Abie B. is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old is married to a businessman and they have four children – two in secondary school and two in primary school.

Abie has operated a small business for many years now. She sells palm-oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), rice, salt, Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), corn, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy more of the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more palm-oil, rice, salt, Margi, corn, etc., to sell

loans.name: Serious Traders Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Serious Traders” group. They are businesspeople with small-scale businesses based in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Fatmata T. (pictured on the right). She is age twenty-seven and was born in Makeni where she is currently residing with her husband and one child. Her husband is a businessman and her child is attending primary school.

For four years now, Fatmata has been selling slippers/flip-flops. With her share of the loan, she will buy dozens of pairs of slippers to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy dozens of pairs of slippers to sell

loans.name: Malap I Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Malap I” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are women with small businesses who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, in order to seek a loan of SLL 1,400,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Adama K. (who is pictured on the left, receiving the loan). Adama was born in a village call Makamabo, very close to Makeni. She is approximately 39 years old, married to a businessman, and the couple has three children – one in primary school and two in secondary school.

Adama owns a small shop where she sells mints, sugar, biscuits, plastic bags, salt, etc. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand the size and quality of her business. She will use the loan to buy more of the above mentioned items in large quantity to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more mints, sugar, biscuits, plastic bags, salt, etc., for her shop

loans.name: Hold Sorbeh Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Hold Sorbeh” group. They are women with small-scale businesses based in Makeni city.  They are requesting a loan of SLL 3,100,000 for the entire group to enable them to further improve on the size and quality of their respective businesses.

Pictured in the left is Fatmata M. who is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Makeni and she is age thirty-two. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children, two of whom are in primary school and one in secondary school.

Fatmata sells “rice-bread” (a cake made out of bananas, flour and sugar) and has had over fifteen years of experience in business. With her share of the loan, she will buy ingredients for making rice-bread – sugar and flour – in large quantity so that she will be able to produce a larger quantity of rice-bread to sell.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to produce a larger quantity of rice-bread

loans.name: Chatherine

texts.en:
Chatherine D. sells bread, tomatoes, onions and cooking oil.  She is 30 years old, married to a peasant and has three children who do not all go to school. 

She took out a loan in order to stock both fresh and dried fish to sell.   With the extra profits from her loan, Chatherine wants to send her children to school.

loans.use: To stock both fresh and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina T. is currently in the business of selling local brew and beer at a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  

She is 33 years old and is married to a husband who is a tailor. She has two children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her pub.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Serieux Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité SÉRIEUX est créé le 17 juillet 2006. Il est composé de 11 femmes issues du même quartier. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de VELINGARA FOULBE MAREWE. 

Les membres ont formé leur groupe par affinité et s'activent toutes dans le domaine commerciale (vente de fruits, de légumes, d'huile de palme et de pâte d'arachide.

Madame Aïssatou BOLO D., à l'extrême droite de la photo, vêtue de bleu avec des rayures verticales en blanc est la présidente du Groupe de Solidarité. 

Elle est âgée de 38 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de pâte d'arachide, d'huile de palme et de fruits. Elle a une bonne expérience dans le domaine d'activité pour l'avoir mené depuis plus de 4 ans. 

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans les différentes charges familiales tout en renforçant son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
The group "Solidarité SÉRIEUX" was created on JuL. 17, 2006. It is composed of 11 women from the same neighborhood. The group is a member of the "Banc Villageois de VELINGARA FOULBE MAREWE". The members formed their own group out of affinity, and do business in a variety of domains (selling fruits, vegetables, palm oil, and peanut butter). Mrs. Aïssatou BOLO D. (far right in the picture, wearing a blue dress with white vertical stripes) is the president of the group "Solidarité SÉRIEUX". She's 38 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She has a small business selling peanut butter, palm oil, and fruits. She has a good experience in this field, since she's been running this business for four years. Her goal is to help her husband with the various expenses of the famiL., as well as to bolster her savings.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm oil, peanut butter, and fruits

loans.name: Sipola

texts.en:
Sipola D. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bread and to cook more Sudanese local beans (fava beans) to sell.  

Sipola is 36 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant and stock more chairs and tables.

loans.use: Stock more bread and cook more Sudanese local beans (fava) to sell

loans.name: C2132 Ukwezi Group

texts.en:
Gaudance is 24 years old and married with two children, 8 and 3 years old. Both of them are in school. Gaudance owns a small business selling various products. This business is profitable because she is able to get all the basic needs of her family such as food, school fees and so on. Gaudance is also the group representative. The group is called UKWEZI in the local language. This group includes five people with various businesses.

Gaudance and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses. This loan will help them purchase more products for their shops, which will allow them to earn more profits. With the extra money, Gaudance expects to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose S. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant built with bamboo and an ironsheet roof. She is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant.  

Rose is 39 years old and is married to an auto-mechanic engineer. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cement the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Nezzikokolima Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
S. Grace holds her two businesses of raising poultry and of retailing in equal measure. She is able to cut both ways in terms of balancing her financial responsibilities with the two.

Not that 35-year-old S. Grace is a past master with a lot of experience in her businesses. Far from it. The happily married mother of two is only three years down the road in her business in Kirinya-Mukono. 

Notwithstanding all the early financial glow in which she has been basking, this sturdy and always reflective woman has had many experiences that have kept her grounded. She knows that one cannot avoid challenges in the course of operating a business. 

Poultry diseases, most especially, have played havoc with her chickens. When diseases strike, they normally kill many of her brood. Poultry is a highly lucrative business in Uganda nowadays, and when losses happen they impact negatively on her finances as she has fewer chickens to sell.
