Mr. NaR. Y., born I. 1958, was selected village bank president. He and his wife, Mrs. Ven Sok, are farmers. They own a small piece of land and grow crops to sell to support their family.

Now they have a problem because their field is infertile soil. To improve production, Mr. NaR. Y. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pay farm laborers.

He is a father of six childR.. Two are seamstresses I. a garment factory, one is a driver, and the others attend school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pay farm laborers.

loans.name: Raima's Group

texts.ru:
Со дня обретения Кыргызстаном независимости прошло около двадцати лет. За эти годы сменилось множество руководителей и политических элит страны. Все они пытались обновить страну и сделать её современной. Но в силу отсутствия политической воли, терпения, а может быть просто искренности в своих намерениях, все их усилия были обречены на крах. В результате в Кыргызстане так и не было построено новых промышленных объектов, а те которые уже существовали, перестали функционировать. В таких условиях, более расторопные люди поняли, что их от безработицы спасёт всё то - же натуральное хозяйство. 
Райма Жусупова – лидер данной группы. Ей пятьдесят два года. Райма с мужем вырастили двоих детей. Старшему сыну двадцать восемь, а дочери двадцать лет. Муж Раймы работает начальником ДЭПа, а Райма – занимается животноводством и продажей молока. Будучи домохозяйкой, Райма находилась дома, но однажды на савдьбу сына им подарили корову. Тогда Райма и начала ухаживать за скотом. С тех прошло уже десять лет и благодаря совместным усилиям Раймы и её мужа, им удалось провести дома ремонт , купить холодильник и выдать дочку замуж. Сейчас Райма от продажи молока зарабатывает около трёх тысяч сомов ежемесячно. Она хочет увеличить свой доход. Для этого она надеется получить этот кредит и закупить овец для откорма. Райма твёрдо намерена расширить свой бизнес и в будущем мечтает построить дом для своего сына. 
Партнёры Раймы по группе:
Бусарахан Хайдаровой пятьдесят два года. Бусарахан выращивает хлопчатник. В этом нелёгком деле ей помогает дочь. Один из её сыновей работает в России, другой – продавец в магазине, и самый младший сын ходит в школу. Муж Бусарахан работает строителем. Бусарахан обратилась за кредитом, так как ей необходимо приобрести минеральные удобрения. 
Гульсорахон Муминовой сорок четыре года. Мужу Гульсорахон пришлось уехать в Россию на заработки. Гульсорахон осталась дома с тремя детьми. Гульсорахон занимается выращиванием хлопка и другой сельхоз продукции. Гульсорахон надеется получить этот кредит, чтобы закупить минеральные удобрения.
Венере Халиковой всего восемнадцать лет. Она ещё не замужем. Венера занимается бизнесом, а именно перепродажей овец. Кроме того, у неё	 есть постоянная работа в столовой. Венера решила обратиться за этим кредитом, так как собирается купить овец для разведения. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Almost twenty years have passed since the day when Kyrgyzstan declared its independence. Many rulers and country's political elites have changed over these years. All of them tried to renew and modernize the country. But due to the lack of political will, patience or maybe simply lack of sincerity, all of their efforts were doomed to fail. As a result, no new manufacturing sites were built in Kyrgyzstan, and those that existed stopped functioning. Under these conditions, the cleverest people understood that their own business will save them from unemployment. Raima J. is the leader of this group. She is fifty-two years old. Raima and her husband raised two children. The oldest son is twenty-eight, and the daughter is twenty years old. Raima's husband works as manager of Traffic Operation Company, and Raima is involved in animal husbandry and selling milk. Previously, she was a homemaker and stayed home, however, one day they were given a cow as a gift for their son's wedding. Since then, Raima started to take care of livestock. Ten years have passed since then, and thanks to joint efforts of Raima and her husband, they were able to repair their home, buy a refrigerator and marry off their daughter. Currently, Raima earns close to three thousand som monthly from sales of milk. She wants to increase her income. She hopes to obtain a loan for this purpose and buy sheep for fattening. Raima is confident in her decision to expand her business and dreams of building a house for her son in the future. Raima's group partners are: Busarahan H. is fifty-two years old. She grows cotton. Her daughter helps her in this difficult business. One of her sons works in Russia, another is a salesperson at a store, and the youngest son goes to school. Busarahan's husband works as a construction worker. She requested this loan because she needs to buy mineral fertilizers. Gulsorahon M. is forty-four years old. Her husband had to go to Russia for work. Gulsorahon stayed home with three children. She is involved in growing cotton and other agricultural crops. She hopes to obtain this loan in order to buy mineral fertilizers. Venera H. is only eighteen years old. She is not yet married. Venera is involved in business, specifically reselling sheep. Besides this, she has permanent job at a cafeteria. Venera decided to request this loan because she plans to buy sheep for breeding.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheep for fattening

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is the resident of a small city called Riwind located near Lahore, Pakistan. She is 30 years of age and came to this city just after her marriage with M. A. who is a fruit vendor. She is the mother of two children, a son and a daughter; both are very young and attend school. 
Safia supports her family by doing sewing work, selling clothes and shawls. She takes the orders from her nearby clients and fulfills them to earn an income. 

She is applying for her third loan from Asasah to financially support her husband's business who will buy seasonal fruits to resell. 
With an earlier Asasah loan she started her sewing business by purchased a sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Naseem Shakil's Group

texts.en:
Naseem S. lives in the city of Riwind, in Pakistan, with her husband and two children. Both of her children attend school.  Her husband has a job in the factory while she sells milk and has some buffaloes at her house. She wants to buy another buffalo because she thinks that she can increase her income by increasing the amount of milk and making more clients. 

There is potential in her business because milk is the product which is used in every house and if she has more milk to sell then she can earn more money. 

She is applying loan for her second loan from Asasah. Her first experience was good and she is hopeful that the results from this loan will be even better.

Note: "In this photo, Hamedi,  the group member, is doing her household work and other members are helping her except Amna who is doing embroider works".

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Mrs. Saren Eam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 20 people who live in Slab Ta Aon village in Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes that will increase their income this year.

Mrs. Saren E., 41 years old, is village bank president. She sells congee and Chinese noodles at her local market to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sophy Meas, is a motorbike taxi driver.

Now they have a problE. because they want to construct their home, but they do not have enough money to build. So Mrs. Saren E. is asking for a loan to buy timber to build her house.

She is a mother of four children. One is a furniture maker, one is a security guard, one is studying in school, and the youngest is two years old.

loans.use: To buy timber to build her house.

loans.name: Altyngul's Group

texts.ru:
Заработать на хлеб насущный и прокормить семью – долг и обязанность каждого человека. Порой эта задача кажется нам чем – то непосильным, требующим неимоверных усилий делом. Однако если понаблюдать за людьми, окружающими нас в повседневной жизни, мы сразу же заметим, что это не такая уж и трудная задача. Всё что требуется человеку, чтобы начать зарабатывать – это прежде всего желание работать. Герои нашей истории хотят работать и трудиться во благо своих семей. Алтынгуль Мамбетова – лидер данной группы. Алтынгуль вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Карабалта. Ей двадцать девять лет. У Алтынгуль двое детей, каждому из которых по восемь и по шесть лет соответственно. Чтобы прокормить семью муж Алтынгуль работает на рынке. Алтынгуль также работает на рынке. Она занимается розничной торговлей детских игрушек. Алтынгуль уверенно ведёт свою бойкую торговлю. Ещё бы, ведь она постоянно ощущает, что рядом с ней муж, который в свободное время всегда рядом с ней и всячески ей помогает. У Алтынгуль стабильный заработок: около десяти тысяч семисот сомов ежемесячно. А ведь семь лет назад, когда они только начинали свой бизнес, всё это выглядело довольно хрупким предприятием. Тогда они получили кредит и вложили около пятнадцати тысяч сомов и купили товар. За последние годы, благодаря начатому делу, им удалось купить дом и обставить его новой мебелью. Алтынгуль обратилась за этим кредитом, так как хочет купить товар в целях увеличения ассортимента. В её дальнейшие планы также входит купить автомашину, отремонтировать дом и купить корову. 
Партнёры Алтынгуль:
Розе Токтоболотовой 35 лет. Она мать троих детей. Все её дети ходят в школу. Муж Розы работает на стройке, а сама Роза занимается торговлей. Роза надеется получить этот кредит и закупить на него товар. 
Бактыгуль Усупбаевой 37 лет. Муж Бактыгуль – пенсионер, а Бактыгуль работает на виноводочном заводе. Всесте они воспитывают двоих детей. Бактыгуль нужен кредит для того, чтобы купить мягкую мебель. 
Мире Мендекеевой 42 года. Мира имеет троих детей и чтобы прокормить семью приходится работать и ей и мужу. Муж занимается перевозкой пассажиров. Мира в свою очередь торгует продовольственными товарами. Она обратилась за этим кредитом, так как  хочет купить товар для увеличения товарооборота. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Earning a living and feeding a family is a debt and responsibility of every person. Sometimes this task seems to us as something unattainable, a task, requiring unbelievable efforts. However, if we observe people surrounding us in our daily lives, we notice right away that it is not such a difficult task. All that a person needs in order to start earning is, before all else, a will to work. The heroes of our story want to work hard and work for the benefit of their families. Altyngul M. is the leader of this group. Altyngul and her family lives in the city of Karabalta. She is twenty-nine years old and has two children, who are eight and six years old. In order to support the family, Altyngul's husband works at a market and so does she. She is involved in retail sales of children's toys. Altyngul confidently leads her busy retail business. She always feels that her husband is next to her, and he helps her however he can in his free time. Altyngul has a stable monthly income of close to ten thousand seven hundred som. And seven years ago, when they first started their business, it looked like a fairly fragile enterprise. Then, they obtained a loan and invested close to fifteen thousand som and bought the merchandise. Over the last few years, thanks to this business, they were able to buy a house and furnish it with new furniture. Altyngul requested this loan because she wants to buys merchandise with the goal of expanding the selection. In the future, her plans also include buying a car, repairing a house and buying a cow. Altyngul's partners are: Roza T. is 35 years old. She is a mother of three children, all of whom go to school. Roza's husband works at a construction site, and Roza is involved in sales. Roza hopes to obtain this loan and buy merchandise. Baktygul U. is 37 years old. Her husband is retired, and Baktygul works at a distillery. Together they are raising two children. Baktygul needs a loan in order to buy furniture. Mira M. is 42 years old. She has three children, and in order to support the family, both she and her husband have to work. Her husband is involved in passenger transportation. Mira is involved in sales of groceries. She requested this loan because she wants to buy merchandise in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase toys to expand merchandise selection

loans.name: Shaar's Group

texts.en: Various ordeals in life are designed to make people stronger and develop spiritual strength and patience. The very same thing happened to the heroine of our story. Shaar A. is the leader of this group. She is 59 and has raised four children. Shaar lost her husband and while her children were growing up. She did her best to be both father and mother for them. Now, her eldest son works in Russia, her younger son works in Kyrgyzstan, and her two daughters are married and live separately. Shaar has done everything possible for her children and now she could at last have rest and live a happy grandmother’s life. However, this is not Shaar’s thinking. She stills works hard to make her own living, as she does not want to depend on her children and still prefers to lead an independent life. She earns her living by breeding livestock. Her husband used to provide for the whole family. After his death, Shaar came face-to-face with the problem of earning daily bread for the whole family. She sells sheep when she needs a large sum, and sells milk to meet her daily needs. Her monthly income comes to around 3000 soms. Shaar hopes to obtain this loan to purchase five sheep and forage. Shaar’s partners: Aiymhan H., 40, is married. Her husband is a carpenter. Aiymhan grows vegetables. She also works as a cook in a local school. Aiymhan has decided to apply for this loan to purchase sheep for feeding. Turganbai T., 63, raises livestock. He and his wife have brought up six children. Turganbai’s wife is a saleswoman in her own shop. One of Turganbai’s children is also engaged in cattle breeding. Turganbai needs this loan to buy construction materials. Risalat K., 59, is a widow. She is the mother of five children. Her daughters are married and live separately. Her son earns his living by repairing cell phones. Risalat makes a living by producing blankets and preparing brides' dowries on order. She needs this loan to purchase materials for making blankets. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase five sheep

loans.name: Mrs. Oeun Bun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people who live in Slab Ta Aon village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Oeun B., 60 years old, is village bank president.

She is a vegetable seller and her husband, Mr. Bech Hem, is a construction worker who also earns a small salary to support the family. They have one daughter who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So Mrs. Oeun B. is asking for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Nabat's Group

texts.en: Manufacturing national articles has always been one of the well-known women’s occupations in Kyrgyzstan. For men, the traditional way of making a living has always been either farming or cattle breeding. However, over the last decades, women have diversified their occupations and started doing various other jobs. As for the production of national articles, it requires lots of patience, love and enthusiasm since, if a woman does not put all her talent and passion into the work, she might not make a good article and her product may be left unsold. The heroines of our story make national articles and are involved in cattle breeding and farming. Nabat S. is 50. She has raised six children. Her daughters are married and live separately. Her only son works in Russia and visits his parents once a year. Nabat’s youngest daughter goes to college. To make a living, Nabat’s husband works as a security guard and Nabat manufactures national articles. She learned this craft from her sister. She would never have dreamed that this acquired skill would become the main source of her income, were it not for the high unemployment rate in the country. Nabat hopes to obtain this loan to purchase fabric for making articles. Nabat’s partners: Parizat C., 45, is a widow. She is the mother of four children. Three of them are working in Russia. Parizat is engaged in cattle breeding. She has sheep and plans to build a new shed. For now, she needs a loan to purchase some sheep. Gulzat K., 37, has two children. Both of them go to school. Gulzat’s husband is a village shepherd. Gulzat is also occupied with cattle breeding and selling milk. She manages to make $170 a month. Gulzat has applied for this loan as she wants to buy a piece of land nearby for building a house. Kandalat S., 43, is married and has four children. Kandalat’s husband has gone to work in Russia and, for now, Kandalat is the sole provider for her family. She breeds cattle and thus manages to earn $105 a month. She needs this loan to purchase sheep to increase the total population of her livestock. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann was encouraged to join ASHI because of the principles of helping women to show their skills through lending her working capital for a business as a micro-entrepreneur. Mary Ann marked the day when she joined ASHI in 2008 At that time she begans to dream, hope, and find a way to moved away under hardship of poverty. Mary Ann is interested in continuing her buying & selling of different small goods to supply additional income for her family, 

Mary Ann would like to receive a loan amounting to 15,000 PHP to purchase more inventory of different small goods.  As a proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a first Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Mary Ann is thankful to have obtained secured capital to support her goals in life. Her long term goals are to build a profitable buying & selling business, send her two children to college, and invest in her home.  With the support of Kiva partner, she is dedicated to expand her business and determined to achieve financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of different small goods.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokheng Toch Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Slab Ta Aon village, in Kandal province, sixteen people make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Sokheng T., born in 1973, is a village bank president. She has been selected by the other members, who will each use a portion of their loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sokheng T. owns a general store in the local village where she earns some money to support her family. Since this business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sokheng T. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sokhom Kham, is a construction worker. Through this activity, they support four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell.

loans.name: Savun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savun M., is 39 years old and her husband, Mr. Run Roem (pictured together), is 50 They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1989 and have five children - three sons and two daughters. One son is learning motorbike repairing skills, one daughter assists her mother in the business and other three children are in school.  

Savun is a flower farmer. She transports her flowers to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a motorbike taxi. She hopes to buy additional flowers to sell, but she does not have capital. Hence she is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to help increase her capital.

loans.use: To finance her capital to purchase flowers for resale.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Mr. Bun S. and his wife, Mrs. Saven Doung, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1989 and have four children; three sons and one daughter. Three of them are in school and help their parents in the business and the youngest one stays at home. 

Mr. Bun S. and his wife are banana and flower farmers. They buy their supplies from farmers in their village and transport them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Bun hasalready made two Kiva loans.  He and his wife hope to increase their income by growing vegetable, but they do not have enough capital.

Hence Bun is requesting another loan in the amount of $1,000 to use for growing vegetable.

loans.use: A loan to use for growing vegetable.

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom C. (in the photo), 24, and her husband, Mr. Chamroeun Yong, 27, have been married for five years and have two children: one son and one daughter. The family lives in a suburb about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sreymom and her husband are garment factory workers. They also grow rice when they are free. The couple does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their rice farm. Therefore, Sreymom is applying for her first loan of $500 to help her capital.

loans.use: To use for growing rice.

loans.name: Nhoeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhoeb S. (shown in the photo with her loom) is 55 years old and her husband, Mr. Sarun Ung, is 56 years old. They live across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1970 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. Five of them are married and live outside the family home and the youngest is in school.

Nhoeb has been a silk weaver for 30 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to a middleman who comes to buy it from her home. Her husband has been a primary teacher for 30 years. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Mrs. Kang A. is a 40-year-old married woman and local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She and her husband use this land to grow different kinds of crops, including potatoes and rice. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. Kang A. doesn’t have capital to use on her field during this coming rainy season. So she is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilizer and seeds to begin growing.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B., from the village of Pagalongan, Wao, Lanao del Sur, is 43 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business venture selling generic medicines to local community members. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional generic medicines to sell, she is requesting her fourth loan for 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase more inventory and as working capital. Evelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina C., from the village of Frankfort, Wao, Lanao del Sur, is 48 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Sabina owns and operates a business selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She also manages a sari-sari store. Engaged in her businesses for over 10 years, she earns approximately 9000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Sabina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 13000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional fish to sell, she is requesting a new loan, her fifth, for 15000 PHP for the same purpose. Sabina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina M. is from the village of Extension, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Carolina is married and has four school-aged children. Carolina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 2008 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2008, Carolina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 10,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Carolina is now requesting her fourth loan from HSPFI, for 13,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Roselia

texts.en:
Roselia Q. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 49 years old. Roselia is married and has seven adult children. Roselia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Roselia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5800 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Roselia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 10,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Roselia is now requesting her fourth loan from HSPFI, for 13,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora C. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 54 years old. Leonora is married and has one adult child. Leonora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2008, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 15,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Leonora is now requesting her sixth loan from HSPFI, for 15,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita K. is from the village of Western, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 54 years old. Lolita is married and has five adult children. Lolita owns and operates a furniture making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 15,000 PHP and was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture.

Lolita is now requesting her sixth loan from HSPFI, for 15,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia T. is from the village of Wao Lanao del Sur. She is 56 years old. Virginia is married and has 7 adult children. Virginia owns and operates a  sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Virginia is now requesting her second loan from HSPFI, for 7000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand it further.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding the business

loans.name: Rheamar

texts.en: Rheamar O. is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 36 years old. Rheamar is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rheamar runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Rheamar has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 9,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Rheamar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rheamar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rheamar is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Rheamar from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Arapathon's Group

texts.en: Arapathon J. is the leader of the group. She is 49 and married. She has raised two sons; both of them work in construction and earn 5,000 soms per month. Three years ago, Arapathon and her husband started to breed cattle. They started with the initial investment of 20,000 soms and now, by selling some animals after fattening, they make 5,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for them to purchase a vehicle. With money received from the loan, Arapathon wants to purchase a calf for breeding and a dowry for her future daughter-in-law. In the future, she plans to increase the number of cattle and contribute some money to her son’s wedding. Gulmira T., 36, is married. Her husband works as a constructor in Russia. They have two daughters and two sons, all of whom study at school. In order to make money, Gulmira breeds cattle. She has been doing it for 21 years. By selling milk and some animals after fattening, Gulmira makes 5,000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf for breeding. Mavzhuda A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 32 and married. Her husband works as a constructor in Russia. They have a son and a daughter; the son is a student and the daughter is not yet a student. Mavzhuda owns some land and she cultivates cotton. She has been doing it for 10 years, and by selling cotton, she makes 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Mavzhuda wants to purchase fertilizers for farming. Narinisa I., 45, is divorced. She has two sons; the older sons works in construction and the second son is a student. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 2,000 soms, Narinisa began to sew the national cloth and dressmaking supplies. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials, and also to finish repairing the house. In the future, Narinisa wants to expand her business, finish repairing the house and contribute some money to her son’s wedding. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI (microfinance institution) in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf for breeding

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en: As a widow, Dominga T. is working hard to be both a mother and, at the same time, a father to her children. At present, she is already 60 years old but still strong and determined to give her best for her four adult children. She and her family live in the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. To make a living, Dominga raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Dominga has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) whenever she sells the raised animal. In 2006, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dominga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Bakyt

texts.en:
Bakyt B. was born in the town of Kara-Balta in the north of the Kyrgyz Republic, where he still lives. He is 29 years old, married and has two children; his son is 6 and his daughter is 3 years old. Bakyt and his family live in his mother’s house. 

He started to work when he was 20. In the beginning, he worked at a private car wash, and later he was hired by a car-repair shop as a mechanical assistаnt.  When he had earned the necessary start-up capital, he bought his first car – a used Ford Sierra. From this moment, he changed his job and became a private taxi driver.

In 2008, Bakyt had a car accident, which was the fault of another driver. Bakyt got injured, and his car became unsuitable for his taxi business, so Bakyt sold it. Bakyt and his family met difficult times as he was the only breadwinner for his family and kids. 

After full recovery, he decided to go back into business and took a loan from the Bai Tushum Company to purchase a car. He bought a Volkswagen Golf produced in 1986. The loan was used for its initial purpose and repaid on time and without any delay. This car is the only means of income in the B. family, but its technical condition does not allow it to carry out safe passenger transportation. The car needs to be repaired.

That’s why Bakyt applied for another loan, to repair his car so that he can continue to work as a taxi driver. Part of the new loan Bakyt wants to use to renovate the house where his family lives.

In the future, Bakyt wants to buy a good minivan with seven seats and continue to work as a taxi driver. Bakyt’s family now lives in a small, old house. Bakyt dreams of buying a good, large house for his family, where they could have their own household.

loans.use: To repair a taxi

loans.name: Encarnacion

texts.en:
Encarnacion B. is from the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. She is 57 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for breeding. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $90 when she sells her raised pig.

In 2005, Encarnacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Encarnacion is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed for the pigs. This will be her 11th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed

loans.name: Ruperto

texts.en:
"I am offering transportation services to my co-villagers, rain or shine", said Ruperto B.. He is from the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. He is 34 years old, married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, he provides motorcycle transport services. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $110 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Ruperto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. Ruperto is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
In his late 40’s, it’s hard to imagine that Frank T., who has been running an agricultural enterprise for over 10 years, is still at his best proving to fellow businessmen that he can make it. Having been inspired by his late father for quite some time, hard-working Frank got a vision to start up a banana-selling business alongside his milk sales enterprise. He has been practicing this from Mugamba, Rukungiri, where he earns approximately $200 on a monthly basis.

However, his main problem is dealing with low quantity harvests; therefore, he needs this loan to purchase mulch and manure for his plantation. This will make it possible for him to earn more revenue and care for his family of seven children and a wife at home.

loans.use: to buy mulches and fertilizer for his banana plantation

loans.name: Halima's Group

texts.en:
Halima lives in a three-room brick house with her husband, named M. J., and her daughter in a city of Pakistan named Burewala. She is a housewife, and stays at home carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother. She also does embroidery work to generate extra income after completing the domestic chores. 

Her husband drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) in the surrounding area.  He has five years of driving experience. Halima is applying for her second loan from Asasah to enable her husband to repair his rickshaw and bring it into good working condition.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Sokheang

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheang Y. is a villager in Trapeang Chrey village, in Takeo province, and she was born in 1984. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. She earns some money at this business to support her family while her husband, Mr. Yung Hing, is a construction worker who is also able to get low salary to support his family. Although both of them try to work hard, they earn too little money. So to improve their family's standard of living, Mrs. Sokheang Y. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This is her effort to start a new business to increase income this current year. She is a mother of two children whom are both too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Kariakoo Group

texts.en:
Mwana Asha L., age 40, is single and has one 17-year-old son.  She lives with her parents.  She sells food like tea with snacks in the morning and lunch at Kariakoo place in the city.  She has been in this business for ten years now. She works from 5am to 5pm daily and she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $473.

This will be Mwana’s 6th loan and her 1st Motisha loan.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended at Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to start selling chips from 5pm to morning.
	
Mwana will share this loan with her loan group, Kariakoo, which totals seven members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

In the picture, Mwana is at the far right.

loans.use: To start seling chips from 5pm up to morning

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila lives in a three-room brick house in a city named Borewala, in Pakistan, with her husband, I. M., and her four children.  She has three daughters and one son. She is a kind and patient housewife. All day her children of different ages have different needs, so she has to take care of them and her house.

Her husband works in a factory earning a monthly wage, and her eldest daughter has been working for a year in a beauty salon. Jamila has applied for a loan for her daughter for the second time. With the loan her daughter will buy the beauty products and make-up supplies needed for starting her own beauty salon. Then she will be able to earn more and utilize her work experience in a better way.
 
Jamila has a good credit record with no delays in repayment. She is confident that this time also she will maintain her good credit behavior.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products and make-up supplies

loans.name: Sokunthea

texts.en: In Melong Khang Tboung village, in Takeo province, 29 year old Mrs. Sokunthea P. is a farmer. She owns a two point seven-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice that she sells to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sok Chea Nget, has a motorbike repair business. Aside from this, he is also a motorbike cleaner who can earn some money to support his family. Currently, Mrs. Sokunthea P. has some problems because her field has infertile soil. So to improve production, she is seeking for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business, and motorbike supplies to use to support her husband’s business. She is a mother of three children who all are enrolled in the local public school. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en: Mrs. Noeun S. is a married woman who lives in Kor village, in Takeo province, and she is 27 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Sao S., are farmers who own a two point five-hectare piece of land where they can grow crops to sell to support their family. Aside from farming she is also a farm laborer while her husband is a construction worker, too. Their field infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mrs. Noeun S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school, while the other is too small to work or study. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Kigaaga Biruga Omututu, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Different genres of agricultural activities have made many Ugandan families have an improved lease on life. This story is connected to one K. Monica from Kigaaga, Ibanda district.

This married lady has subsisted on the profits from selling a variety of agricultural products, for the last ten years specializing in growing bananas. Though adverse weather conditions have constantly affected her plantations, she has managed to consolidate the gains she has made. As a result, her family of four children has enjoyed the benefits; principally, her children all now attend good institutions of learning. 

In a month, Monica reveals that she makes close to or even more than $90 out of selling her agricultural produce. She is very upbeat that with this loan she will be in a position to improve on the mulching and gardening aspects of her farm, and also to increase her stock of animals on the farm which will help her increase the produce and sales revenue.

Monica is the lady seated on the far left with her hand raised, and the others with hands raised are the secretary, treasurer and vice chairman for the group.

loans.use: purchasing mulches and fertilizers for the plantation

loans.name: Kausar Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Kausar parveen is the wife of S. A.. She is the mother of six children, three sons and three daughters. This family lives in a three-room brick house in a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. Kausar is a housewife and takes care of her young children and her family.

S. runs a grocery shop while his eldest son is a driver by trade. His son has nine years of driving experience. Kausar has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah so her husband can expand his business. With the loan he will buy groceries in bulk and expand his grocery shop.  

They hope that from the profit of this loan they will make their brick house into a cement house.

loans.use: Purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Gaudencia

texts.en:
Charcoal is the most common means of cooking foods for the poor people living in very remote areas of the province, just like the family of Gaudencia G.. Being poor, they cannot afford to buy gas and a gas stove so they settle on using charcoal instead. Aside from its affordable price, it is also the most conveniently accessed commodity for everyone from their distant village. 

Gaudencia thought of buying a large volume of charcoal for a wholesaling (by sack instead of per pack) business.  In 2005, she joined ASHI and was able to receive a loan which enabled her to establish such a plan. Years have passed and Gaudencia continued to request loans of increasing amounts. With those loans, she has been able to sustain her business, and the proceeds of the business are used to support the needs of her family and in making a little improvement to their lives.

She now is 68 years old, yet she and her husband, who is of the same age, are still working hard to earn money and support the poor lives of their children and grandchildren. Gaudencia’s husband works in a rice farm as a hired laborer, but most of the time he partners with his wife in her charcoal business. 

Gaudencia and husband really want to grow their business and make it profitable for their children and grandchildren, so that they can experience a life out from under poverty. Because of this, the woman would like to request a much larger loan through ASHI. With hopes of changing the lives of her children and her grandchildren in the future, she is determined to maintain her excellent performance in ASHI to be able to request for more loans in the future.

loans.use: To purchase larger volumes of charcoal for a wholesale business.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: Mrs. Nan C. is a villager in Melong Khang Cheung village, Takeo province, and she was born in 1974. She is a meat and beef seller at her local market. She earns some money to help support her family while her husband, Mr. Chhoeurn Ouch, is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land where he can grow rice to be able earn some money to support his family. Aside from farming he is also a motorbike taxi driver. Now her husband’s field has some problems because it has infertile soil and it is has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mrs. Nan C. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are studying in the local public school, while the youngest one is five-years-old. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Salako

texts.fr: S. Salako est né le 08 Février 1973 au Bénin. Salako est marié à AMOUSSOU Antoinette, une ménagère. Le couple a cinq enfants à leur charge, dont trois sont leurs enfants. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a une quinzaine d'année que Salako  vit à Djèrègbé, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec sa famille. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Salako n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. C'est un mécanicien-auto qui mène cette activité depuis dix ans. Parallèlement, Salako vend des pièces détachées (Produits de casse auto) à Djèrègbé. Salako achète ses produits au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Salako sollicite un prêt de ALIDé, prêt qui lui servira à augmenter le stock de ses pièces de rechange et à augmenter son revenu.
texts.en:
Mr. S. Salako was born on February 8, 1973 in Benin.  He is married to Ms. AMOUSSOU Antoinette, a housewife.  The couple have five children in their care.  Three of the children are their own.  Only some of them are in school.  Salako has been living with his family for about fifteen years in Djèrègbé, in the community of Sèmè-Podji.   The couple jointly cover family expenses.  Salako attended primary school only.  He is an auto mechanic who has been in this business for ten years.  Concurrently, he sells spare parts (car repair goods) in Djèrègbé.  He buys his goods from Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  This is the first time that Salako has requested a loan from ALIDé.  It will be used to increase his stock of replacement parts and to increase his revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying spare parts

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily T. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Purok Risal, Barangay Manalad, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: hog fattening, and a general store.

Emily’s husband Armando is a driver, and they have three children who are between 12 and 18 years old.  The two younger children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Emily joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her two businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of $183 from her business activities.

She is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for the 5th time, this loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP, which she intends to use on her hog fattening business. Emily is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned their respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey M., 54 years old, is a villager in Dei Chrab village in Takeo province. She is an age seller who is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ba Em, is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. 

While they both try to work hard, they still earn too little money. So to improve their family's living, Mrs. Srey M. is seeking a loan to buy a cow to raise. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer to support her husband’s field and increase rice yield this year.

They have three children. One helps with the parents’ businesses and the other two attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap K., born in 1977, lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can earn some money to help support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ven Chan, is a pig middleman who also earns a little income.

Mrs. Sopheap K. is seeking a loan to buy more pigs to resell and to increase their income.

She is a mother of four children. One is a car and motorbike cleaner and the others are enrolled in local public school.

loans.use: To buy pigs to resell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy L.  is a 43-year old married woman who lives in Poblacion, San Jose, Negros Oriental.  She earns her living by operating her vegetable and fruit vending businesses.

Lucy’s husband, Pablio, is a driver and they have 2 children who are 13 and 15 years old.  Both children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Lucy  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a vegetable and fruit vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP13,000 from her business activities.

She is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP13,000 was used to fund the operations of her vegetable vending, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 8th loan, in the amount of PHP25,000, which she intends to use on her vegetable and fruit vending business. Lucy  is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en:
Mrs. Ky K., 49 years old, is a villager in Chuos village in Takeo province. To support her family she is a cake maker. Her husband, Mr. Hien Ben, is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family.

Although they try to work hard they earn only a little money. To improve their family's living, Mrs. Ky K. is seeking a loan to buy five piglets and pig food for breeding. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer and rent a plow to plow her husband’s field.

They have four children. Two are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other two are laborers in Thailand.

loans.use: To buy five piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Alona

texts.en:
Alona S. is a 38-year old married  woman who lives in Villamil St., Brgy. Tandayag, Amlan, Negros Oriental.  She earns her living by operating her 2 business ventures; Peanut Grinding and motorcycle transportation.

Alona’s husband Albert  is a Tricycle driver, and they have 4 Children who are between 4 months  and 19 years old.  The 3 older children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Alona  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a peanut grinding and tricycle transportation business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 8,400 from her business activities.

Alona is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP10,000 was used to fund operations of her tricycle transportation business and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 20th loan, in  the amount of PHP19,500, which she intends to use on her Peanut grinding business. Alona is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Augustine Ayadjénou

texts.fr: D. Augustine Ayadjénou est née en 1967 à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à MINDENOU Alexandre, Augustine est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a deux autres enfants à leur charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Il y a près de vingt trois ans que Augustine s'est installée à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-POdji, où elle vit avec sa famille. Augustine vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges familiales. Augustine a très tôt abandonné l'école, puis a appris la coiffure. Augustine exerce cette activité depuis une quiinzaine d'année. Augustine mène cette activité à son domicile. Parallèlement, Augustine vend des mèches. Augustine s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Augustine sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé, en vue d'acheter beaucoup de mèches et de réaliser des perruques qu'elle mettra en vente.
texts.en:
Augustine Ayadjénou D. was born in 1967 at Djeffa, in the Sèmè-Podji commune in Bénin. Married to Alexandre MINDENOU, Augustine is the mother of six children, all of whom are in school. In addition to their children, the couple has two other children in their care. Augustine settled in Lokokoukoumè in the Sèmè-Podji commune nearly three years ago, where she lives with her family. She helps her husband to provide for the family’s various expenses. She left school very early and then learned hairdressing. Augustine has been in this business for about fifteen years and runs her business at her home. In addition, she sells hair pieces. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. This is the first time that Augustine has requested financial assistance from ALIDé, so that she can buy many hairpieces and make wigs that she will sell.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase boxes of hair pieces.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is the wife of M. A. and the mother of one child. Sajawal Abbas is her son's name. This family of three lives in a two room brick house in a city in Pakistan named Borewala.  

A. is a salesman, selling school bags. He has an experience of two years.   

A very talented lady, Nasreen operates a domestic-sewing business. She does this work to financially support her husband. Her client base are her neighbors. She sews their clothes and receives a reasonable income from this. She can sew designer and non designer clothes easily.  
Nasreen has taken three loans from ASASAH and successfully repaid them. She maintained a good credit behavior every year. Now she is applying for the fourth time for a loan from Asasah to expand the business of her husband. With the loan amount her husband will buy the school bags in bulk to meet the orders of his customers.

loans.use: Purchase school bags for resale

loans.name: Lucile

texts.en:
Lucile O. is a 46 year old married woman who supports her family by selling cell phone accessories and phone card reloading business. She lives in Tambongon, San Remegio, Cebu City with her husband and their 2 children who are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her selling of cell phone accessories and cell phone card reloading business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000.

Lucile is borrowing Php 29,500 so that she could use it as an additional working capital for her businesses. This will be her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lucile aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine G. is from the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. She is 40 years old. Catherine is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Catherine raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Catherine has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Though most of the farmers in their village are men, she does not mind it at all; in fact, she treats that as a motivation to work harder. Catherine added that she is proud because she was able to help her husband in managing their farming business. In 2007, Catherine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catherine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. Catherine is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Catherine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Shamim akhtar lives in a two room cement house with her six children and her husband, M. I., in a city in Pakistan named Borewala. Shamim has three daughters and three sons.  I. owns a business selling crockery and in his business his three sons also help out. I. has eight years experience in selling crockery.  

Shamim is a housewife. She takes care of her house and her three daughters who are in their twenties. They help their mother with the work which gives Shamim a proud feeling.

She has taken three loans from ASASAH and successfully repaid them and maintained a good credit performance continuously for three years. Now she has applied for a fourth loan from Asasah for her husband and sons. With the loan they will buy crockery in bulk and their own shop in themarket to earn a better profit. 

From the profit earned from the last three loans, Shamim and her family bought a color television and renovated their house.

loans.use: To purchase crokery for reselling

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria N. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Sacsac, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: pig fattening and farming businesses. Her husband, Zacarias N., 57 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business. They have four children who are 20 to 31 years old. Victoria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she hoped for something better for her family. Victoria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow and with the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000; thus, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan cycle, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use for her livestock and to purchase fertilizer for farming so that she can continue to save up for future additional capital for her business. Victoria N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for pig fattening and farming needs

texts.en: Elvira B. is a 56-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store business. She lives in Purok II, Barangay Gargato, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. Elvira has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Elvira aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. loans.name: Y. Philomène

texts.fr: D. Y. Philomène est née le 22 Septembre 1984 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Philomène vit depuis son jeune âge à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Philomène est mariée à SOTIN Gilbert, un menuisier. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble; Philomène vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges familiales. Philomène n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la coiffure. Philomène exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans. A côté de cette activité, Philomène vend des mèches et des produits cosmétiques dans son salon de coiffure. Philomène achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Compte tenu du nombre important de demandes enregistrées, Philomène désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Philomène sollicite un prêt.
texts.en:
Y. Philomène D. was born September 22, 1984 in Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. Philomène has lived from a young age in Lokokoukoumè, located in the commune of Sèmè-Podji. Philomène is married to Gilbert SOTIN, a carpenter. The couple has three dependent children, all in school. They all live together. Philomène helps her husband and together, they provide for the family’s needs. Philomène never went to school but she did learn hairdressing. She has been practicing this activity for five years. To supplement that income, she sells hair extensions and beauty products out of her salon. Philomène gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Given the large number of orders she has received, Philomène wishes to increase her stocks in order to better serve her customers, which is why she is requesting a loan.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and cosmetics
